output.search_result:
Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, faced significant legal actions for orchestrating extensive market manipulation and fraud schemes. In April 2022, he and former CFO Patrick Halligan were charged with racketeering, conspiracy, securities fraud, and wire fraud. ([cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2022/04/27/archegos-owner-hwang-former-cfo-halligan-charged-with-fraud.html?utm_source=openai)) The indictment alleged that Hwang used Archegos to manipulate stock prices and misled banks to secure billions in loans, leading to the firm's collapse in March 2021. ([cbsnews.com](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/archegos-bill-hwang-collapse-fraud-arrest-sec/?utm_source=openai))

In July 2024, after a nine-week trial, Hwang was convicted on ten counts, including racketeering conspiracy, securities fraud, market manipulation, and wire fraud. The jury found that Hwang's actions caused over $9 billion in losses to major investment banks and led to a $100 billion collapse in market value when Archegos failed. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/founder-and-head-archegos-capital-management-bill-hwang-sentenced-18-years-prison?utm_source=openai))

On December 19, 2024, Hwang was sentenced to 18 years in prison for his role in the fraud. Prosecutors described his conduct as "weaponizing" his hedge fund to commit financial fraud on a national scale. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/founder-and-head-archegos-capital-management-bill-hwang-sentenced-18-years-prison?utm_source=openai))

This case underscores the severe consequences of financial misconduct and the commitment of regulatory bodies like the DOJ and SEC to hold individuals accountable for such actions.

([washingtonpost.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2024/11/20/archegos-hwang-sentence-prison/?utm_source=openai)) The firm's downfall resulted in over $10 billion in losses for major banks, including Credit Suisse and Nomura Holdings. ([cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/11/20/archegos-bill-hwang-sentenced-to-18-years-in-prison-for-massive-us-fraud.html?utm_source=openai)) Hwang was convicted on 10 counts, including wire fraud and market manipulation, and was sentenced to 18 years in prison in November 2024. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/archegos-bill-hwang-be-sentenced-massive-us-fraud-2024-11-20/?utm_source=openai)) Following the collapse, his net worth was reported to have fallen to approximately $55 million. ([bloomberg.com](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-11-18/once-worth-30-billion-hwang-says-he-s-just-a-millionaire-now?utm_source=openai)) Archegos utilized total return swaps to amass large positions in companies like ViacomCBS and Discovery Communications, allowing them to take on significant leverage without directly owning the stocks. ([forbes.com](https://www.forbes.com/sites/hanktucker/2021/03/31/archegos-capitals-bill-hwang-put-590-million-in-his-charitable-foundation-heres-where-it-went/?utm_source=openai)) This strategy led to inflated stock prices and, when the market turned, the firm was unable to meet margin calls, resulting in a rapid liquidation of positions and substantial losses. output.search_result:
In 2012, Sung Kook "Bill" Hwang, founder of Tiger Asia Management LLC, pleaded guilty to insider trading charges related to Chinese bank stocks. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) alleged that Hwang and his firm engaged in illegal trading by short-selling shares of Bank of China Ltd. and China Construction Bank Corp. based on confidential information obtained from private placement offerings. They subsequently covered these short positions using shares purchased at a significant discount, resulting in illicit profits. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/newsroom/press-releases/2012-2012-264htm?utm_source=openai))

In a parallel criminal case, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of New Jersey charged Tiger Asia Management with wire fraud. The firm pleaded guilty and agreed to forfeit over $16 million in illegal profits. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/archive/usao/nj/Press/files/Tiger%20Asia%20Plea%20and%20Sentencing%20News%20Release.html?utm_source=openai))

As part of the civil settlement with the SEC, Hwang and his firms agreed to pay a total of $44 million, which included disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and penalties. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/newsroom/press-releases/2012-2012-264htm?utm_source=openai))

These actions led to the closure of Tiger Asia Management, and Hwang subsequently established Archegos Capital Management in 2013 as a family office. ([cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/30/meet-bill-hwang-the-man-behind-archegos-capital-management.html?utm_source=openai))

Sung Kook "Bill" Hwang is a South Korean-born American investor and trader, best known as the founder of Archegos Capital Management, which collapsed in 2021, leading to significant financial losses for major investment banks.

**Early Life and Education**

Born in South Korea, Hwang immigrated to the United States in 1982. After his father's death in 1983, he and his mother relocated to Los Angeles, where he worked night shifts at McDonald's to support his family and fund his education. He earned a Bachelor of Arts in Economics/Business from the University of California, Los Angeles, and an MBA from Carnegie Mellon University's Tepper School of Business. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Hwang?utm_source=openai))

**Career History**

Hwang began his career in the early 1990s as an equity salesperson at Hyundai Securities in New York. He later worked at Peregrine Investments Holdings, where he met billionaire hedge fund manager Julian Robertson. Robertson, impressed by Hwang's expertise, brought him into his firm, Tiger Management. After Tiger Management closed in 2000, Robertson provided Hwang with approximately $25 million to start his own hedge fund, Tiger Asia Management, which grew to over $5 billion at its peak. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Hwang?utm_source=openai))

In 2012, Tiger Asia Management pleaded guilty to insider trading of Chinese bank stocks and paid a $44 million fine. Subsequently, Hwang closed the fund and, in 2013, founded Archegos Capital Management, a family office managing his personal assets. Archegos employed highly leveraged positions in total return swaps, allowing it to amass large, concentrated holdings in companies like ViacomCBS, Baidu, and Farfetch without public disclosure. In March 2021, Archegos defaulted on margin calls, leading to significant losses for banks such as Credit Suisse and Nomura Holdings. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Hwang?utm_source=openai))

**Legal Issues and Conviction**

In April 2022, Hwang and his former top lieutenant, Patrick Halligan, were arrested and charged with racketeering, conspiracy, securities fraud, and wire fraud. Prosecutors alleged that they misled banks to secure billions, inflating stock prices and contributing to $100 billion in shareholder losses and $10 billion in bank losses. In March 2021, Archegos Capital Management, a family office founded by Bill Hwang, collapsed after defaulting on margin calls from several major investment banks. This led to significant financial losses for these institutions.

**Background:**

Archegos Capital, managing over $36 billion in assets, employed high leverage through total return swaps to amass large, concentrated positions in stocks such as ViacomCBS, Baidu, and Tencent Music. This strategy allowed Archegos to gain substantial exposure without directly owning the underlying shares, keeping its positions hidden from the public and its counterparties. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archegos_Capital_Management?utm_source=openai))

**Collapse and Margin Calls:**

In late March 2021, a decline in the share prices of these holdings triggered margin calls from Archegos' prime brokers. Unable to meet these demands, Archegos defaulted, prompting the banks to liquidate the positions. This forced sale of assets resulted in significant losses for the involved banks.

**Financial Impact on Banks:**

- **Credit Suisse:** Reported a loss of approximately $5.5 billion due to the Archegos collapse. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2021/apr/27/nomura-and-ubs-latest-banks-to-reveal-impact-of-archegos-collapse?utm_source=openai))

- **Nomura Holdings:** Announced a loss of about $2.9 billion related to the event. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/2021/apr/27/nomura-and-ubs-latest-banks-to-reveal-impact-of-archegos-collapse?utm_source=openai))

- **Morgan Stanley:** Suffered a loss of $911 million, which included a $644 million credit loss and $267 million in trading losses. ([theguardian.com](https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2021/apr/16/china-record-growth-recovery-ftse-100-dow-bitcoin-business-live?utm_source=openai))

- **UBS Group AG:** Reported an unexpected loss of $774 million from the collapse. ([cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/27/ubs-nomura-push-global-banks-archegos-losses-over-10-billion.html?utm_source=openai))

**Legal Consequences:**

In 2024, Bill Hwang was convicted on multiple counts, including securities fraud and racketeering, and was sentenced to 18 years in prison. His former CFO, Patrick Halligan, was also convicted and received an eight-year sentence. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/archegos-bill-hwang-deserves-21-years-prison-us-says-2024-11-16/?utm_source=openai))

output.search_result:
Patrick Halligan, former Chief Financial Officer (CFO) of Archegos Capital Management, was convicted in July 2024 on charges including securities fraud, wire fraud, and racketeering conspiracy. He was sentenced to eight years in prison in January 2025. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/former-archegos-cfo-halligan-gets-8-year-prison-sentence-2025-01-27/?utm_source=openai))

During the trial, Halligan's former colleagues, including Chief Risk Officer Scott Becker and Head Trader William Tomita, testified against him after pleading guilty to related charges and agreeing to cooperate with prosecutors. Becker, for instance, described being instructed to mislead banks about Archegos' financial condition to secure additional credit. ([bloomberg.com](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-09-03/ex-archegos-risk-head-who-testified-against-hwang-avoids-prison?utm_source=openai))

Halligan's defense team challenged the credibility of these witnesses, highlighting their motivations to testify in exchange for leniency in their own cases. They argued that Becker's prior animosity towards Halligan undermined his testimony. ([investmentnews.com](https://www.investmentnews.com/ria-news/archegos-founder-says-case-against-him-makes-no-sense/255112?utm_source=openai))

The trial also focused on the actions of Archegos founder Bill Hwang, who was convicted on multiple counts, including wire fraud, securities fraud, and market manipulation, and was sentenced to 18 years in prison in November 2024. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/archegos-bill-hwang-be-sentenced-massive-us-fraud-2024-11-20/?utm_source=openai))

The convictions of Halligan and Hwang underscore the significant legal repercussions stemming from the collapse of Archegos Capital Management, which led to substantial financial losses for major banks and investors.

output.search_result:
Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, was sentenced to 18 years in prison on November 20, 2024, for orchestrating a massive fraud that led to the firm's collapse in March 2021. The collapse resulted in over $10 billion in losses for Wall Street banks and caused more than $100 billion in shareholder losses. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/archegos-bill-hwang-be-sentenced-massive-us-fraud-2024-11-20/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to the prison term, Hwang was ordered to pay restitution exceeding $9 billion to victims, including former Archegos employees who lost substantial amounts of their deferred compensation. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/founder-and-head-archegos-capital-management-bill-hwang-sentenced-18-years-prison?utm_source=openai))

The restitution amount for former employees was determined to be approximately $32.99 million, divided among 39 individuals. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/us-dis-crt-sd-new-yor/117545944.html?utm_source=openai))

Prosecutors had initially sought a 21-year prison sentence and asset forfeiture of $12.35 billion, but the court did not impose the asset forfeiture. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/archegos-bill-hwang-deserves-21-years-prison-us-says-2024-11-16/?utm_source=openai))

Hwang's co-defendant, former Archegos Chief Financial Officer Patrick Halligan, was sentenced to eight years in prison on January 27, 2025, for his role in the firm's collapse. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/former-archegos-cfo-halligan-gets-8-year-prison-sentence-2025-01-27/?utm_source=openai))

Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, co-founded the Grace and Mercy Foundation in 2006, a Christian charitable organization that received substantial funding from Hwang. Between 2015 and 2018, Hwang donated over $500 million to the foundation, which primarily supported evangelical institutions and nonprofits. ([forbes.com](https://www.forbes.com/sites/hanktucker/2021/03/31/archegos-capitals-bill-hwang-put-590-million-in-his-charitable-foundation-heres-where-it-went/?utm_source=openai))

Following the 2021 collapse of Archegos, which resulted in significant financial losses and legal consequences for Hwang, questions arose regarding the foundation's financial activities. In 2022, a former Archegos managing director filed a lawsuit alleging that employees were coerced into contributing their bonuses to the foundation. The lawsuit claimed that these funds were invested in stocks transferred to the foundation, which were then sold for profit, allowing Archegos to benefit from tax deductions while the foundation avoided capital gains taxes. ([ministrywatch.com](https://ministrywatch.com/lawsuit-former-archegos-employee-alleges-company-hwang-coerced-him-into-supporting-christian-charitable-fund/?utm_source=openai))

In March 2021, Archegos Capital Management, a family office managing assets for Bill Hwang, defaulted on margin loans after significant losses on a concentrated portfolio of risky stocks. This event exposed regulatory gaps, particularly concerning the use of equity total return swaps, which allowed Archegos to gain exposure to stocks without direct ownership, thereby avoiding disclosure requirements. ([congress.gov](https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/IF11825?utm_source=openai))

In response, the SEC proposed new rules in December 2021 to enhance transparency in security-based swaps. These proposals aimed to:

- **Prohibit Fraudulent Conduct**: Implement Rule 9j-1 to prevent fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative conduct in security-based swap transactions. ([fia.org](https://www.fia.org/sites/default/files/2022-03/The%20Archegos%20Rules%20Distribution%20030322.pdf?utm_source=openai))

- **Protect Compliance Officers**: Enact Rule 15Fh-4(c) to shield chief compliance officers from undue influence or coercion. ([fia.org](https://www.fia.org/sites/default/files/2022-03/The%20Archegos%20Rules%20Distribution%20030322.pdf?utm_source=openai))

- **Enhance Position Reporting**: Introduce Rule 10B-1, requiring prompt disclosure of large security-based swap positions exceeding specified thresholds. ([fia.org](https://www.fia.org/sites/default/files/2022-03/The%20Archegos%20Rules%20Distribution%20030322.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Specifically, Rule 10B-1 proposed that investors disclose swap positions within one business day if they exceeded $300 million or 5% of a company's outstanding equity securities. This measure aimed to prevent market manipulation and insider trading. ([daypitney.com](https://www.daypitney.com/insights/publications/2022/09/fog4-the-archegos-scandal-the-sec-responds/?utm_source=openai))

The SEC also considered reforms to family office regulations. Historically, family offices were exempt from certain SEC regulations, including registration as investment advisers. The Archegos incident prompted discussions about potentially removing this exemption to subject family offices to enhanced reporting requirements, thereby increasing regulatory oversight. ([congress.gov](https://www.congress.gov/crs-product/IF11825?utm_source=openai))

output.search_result:
The Grace and Mercy Foundation, established in 2006 by Bill Hwang and his wife, has been implicated in fraudulent conveyance activities related to Archegos Capital Management. The foundation received substantial assets from Archegos, including shares in companies like Netflix, Amazon, Facebook, Expedia, and Hawaiian Airlines. These assets were transferred to the foundation, sold, and the proceeds were used to benefit Hwang, his family, and associates, often without the knowledge or consent of Archegos employees. ([assets.bwbx.io](https://assets.bwbx.io/documents/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/rPKOaCBolLng/v0?utm_source=openai))

In July 2022, a lawsuit was filed against the Grace and Mercy Foundation, alleging that it served as an alter ego of Archegos, facilitating the diversion of assets to shield them from creditors. The lawsuit seeks to recover these assets for the benefit of Archegos' creditors. ([assets.bwbx.io](https://assets.bwbx.io/documents/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/rPKOaCBolLng/v0?utm_source=openai))

In bankruptcy proceedings, trustees can pursue fraudulent conveyance claims under sections 544 and 548 of the Bankruptcy Code. These sections allow trustees to recover assets transferred within specified periods before the bankruptcy filing if the transfers were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors, or for less than reasonably equivalent value. ([jdsupra.com](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/the-clawback-process-in-bankruptcy-what-5401276/?utm_source=openai))

The outcome of the lawsuit against the Grace and Mercy Foundation will significantly impact the recovery of assets for Archegos' creditors. If successful, the recovered assets could be distributed among creditors, potentially mitigating some of the financial losses resulting from Archegos' collapse.

output.search_result:
On June 17, 2025, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) formally withdrew proposed Rule 10B-1, which aimed to require the public reporting of large security-based swap positions. This decision was announced in the Federal Register, Volume 90, Issue 115. ([govinfo.gov](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2025-06-17/html/2025-11110.htm?utm_source=openai))

The SEC's withdrawal of Rule 10B-1 followed a series of developments:

- **June 2023**: The SEC reopened the comment period for the proposed rule, seeking additional feedback from stakeholders. ([sullcrom.com](https://www.sullcrom.com/insights/memo/2023/June/SEC-Reopens-Comment-Period-for-Proposed-Security-Based-Swap-Position-Reporting-Rule?utm_source=openai))

- **June 2023**: The SEC adopted other rules related to security-based swaps, such as Rule 9j-1, which expanded antifraud and anti-manipulation measures, and prohibited undue influence over chief compliance officers. ([jonesday.com](https://www.jonesday.com/en/insights/2023/06/sec-adopts-two-rules-for-securitybased-swaps-but-not-proposed-rule-10b1?utm_source=openai))

Industry participants, including the Committee on Capital Markets Regulation, expressed concerns about the proposed rule's cost-benefit analysis. They argued that the analysis failed to sufficiently quantify the benefits and costs of the proposal, particularly regarding its impact on market participants and the broader financial system. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/comments/s7-32-10/s73210-20120760-272940.pdf?utm_source=openai))

The SEC's decision to withdraw Rule 10B-1 indicates a shift in regulatory priorities, moving away from certain proposals introduced during the previous administration. This move suggests a reevaluation of the proposed rule's potential impact and a response to industry feedback regarding its feasibility and effectiveness. ([pwc.com](https://www.pwc.com/us/en/industries/financial-services/library/our-take/06-13-2025.html?utm_source=openai))

It's possible that such a case has not been publicly reported or is not readily accessible through available sources.

However, there have been notable developments in related cases involving fraudulent conveyance and clawback actions in the context of financial settlements:

- **Second Circuit Ruling on Bankruptcy Code's "Safe Harbor" Provision**: On September 19, 2024, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that the "safe harbor" provision of Section 546(e) of the Bankruptcy Code preempts state law fraudulent conveyance claims. This decision clarifies the protection afforded to certain parties receiving payments from companies in leveraged buyouts and recapitalizations that might otherwise be avoidable under state law when the company files for bankruptcy. ([dlapiper.com](https://www.dlapiper.com/en-ae/insights/publications/2024/10/second-circuit-rules-safe-harbor-provision-preempts-state-law-fraudulent-transfer-claims?utm_source=openai))

- **U.S. Settlement in Madoff Victim Fund Case**: In December 2023, the U.S. Department of Justice announced a settlement with FULCRUM, an investment firm that had fraudulently obtained payments from the Madoff Victim Fund. FULCRUM agreed to pay $2,511,084 to the United States and acknowledged that neither it nor its clients were entitled to future payments from the Fund. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/us-settles-lawsuit-alleging-investment-firm-fraudulently-obtained-payments-madoff?utm_source=openai))

These cases highlight ongoing efforts to address fraudulent conveyance and clawback actions within the financial sector. If you have more specific details or context regarding the Grace and Mercy Foundation case, please provide them, and I can assist further.
